Understanding Quaternions

Posted on June 25, 2012 by Jeremiah

Understanding Quaternions

In this article I will attempt to explain the concept of Quaternions in an easy to understand way. I will explain how you might visualize a Quaternion as well as explain the different operations that can be applied to quaternions. I will also compare applications of matrices, euler angles, and quaternions and try to explain when you would want to use quaternions instead of Euler angles or matrices and when you would not.

You cannot fully understand quaternions in just 45 minutes.
This article is extremely math intensive and is not intended for the weak-hearted.

Introduction

In computer graphics, we use transformation matrices to express a position in space (translation) as well as its orientation in space (rotation). Optionally, a single transformation matrix can also be used to express the scale or “shear” of an object. We can think of this transformation matrix as a “basis space” where if you multiply a vector or a point (or even another matrix) by a transformation matrix you “transform” that vector, point or matrix into the space represented by that matrix.

In this article, I will not discuss the details of transformation matrices. For a detailed description of transformation matrices, you can refer to my previous article titled Matrices.

In this article, I want to discuss an alternative method of describing the orientation of an object (rotation) in space using quaternions.

The concept of quaterinions was realized by the Irish mathematician Sir William Rowan Hamilton on Monday October 16th 1843 in Dublin, Ireland. Hamilton was on his way to the Royal Irish Academy with his wife and as he was passing over the Royal Canal on the Brougham Bridge he made a dramatic realization that he immediately carved into the stone of the bridge.

i2=j2=k2=ijk=−1i2=j2=k2=ijk=−1

William Rowan Hamilton Plaque on Broome Bridge on the Royal Canal commemorating his discovery of the fundamental formula for quaternion multiplication.

Complex Numbers

Before we can fully understand quaterions, we must first understand where they came from. The root of quaternions is based on the concept of the complex number system.

In addition to the well-known number sets (Natural, Integer, Real, and Rational), the Complex Number system introduces a new set of numbers called imaginary numbers. Imaginary numbers were invented to solve certain equations that had no solutions such as:

x2+1=0x2+1=0

To solve this expression, we must state that x2=−1x2=−1 which we know is not possible because the square of any number (positive or negative) is always positive.

Mathematicians generally can’t accept that an expression does not have a solution so a new term was invented called the imaginary number that can be used to solve such equations.

The imaginary number has the form:

i2=−1i2=−1

Don’t try to actually understand this term as there is no logical reason why it exists. We just have to accept that ii is just something that squares to −1−1.

The set of imaginary numbers can be represented by II.

The set of complex numbers (represented by the symbol CC) is the sum of a real number and an imaginary number and has the form:

z=a+bi  a,b∈R,  i2=−1z=a+bi  a,b∈R,  i2=−1

It could also be stated that all Real numbers are complex numbers with b=0b=0 and all imaginary numbers are complex numbers with a=0a=0.

Adding and Subtracting Complex Numbers

Complex numbers can be added and subtracted by adding or subtracting the real, and imaginary parts.

Addition:

(a1+b1i)+(a2+b2i)=(a1+a2)+(b1+b2)i(a1+b1i)+(a2+b2i)=(a1+a2)+(b1+b2)i

Subtraction:

(a1+b1i)−(a2+b2i)=(a1−a2)+(b1−b2)i(a1+b1i)−(a2+b2i)=(a1−a2)+(b1−b2)i

Multiply a Complex Number by a Scalar

A complex number is multiplied by a scalar by multiplying each term of the complex number by the scalar:

λ(a+bi)=λa+λbiλ(a+bi)=λa+λbi

Product of Complex Numbers

Complex numbers can also be multiplied by applying normal algebraic rules.

z1z2z1z2=====(a1+b1i)(a2+b2i)(a1+b1i)(a2+b2i)a1a2+a1b2i+b1a2i+b1b2i2(a1a2−b1b2)+(a1b2+b1a2)iz1=(a1+b1i)z2=(a2+b2i)z1z2=(a1+b1i)(a2+b2i)=a1a2+a1b2i+b1a2i+b1b2i2=(a1a2−b1b2)+(a1b2+b1a2)i

Square of Complex Numbers

A complex number can also be squared by multiplying by itself:

zz2===(a+bi)(a+bi)(a+bi)(a2−b2)+2abiz=(a+bi)z2=(a+bi)(a+bi)=(a2−b2)+2abi

Complex Conjugate

The conjugate of a complex number is a complex number with the imaginary part negated and is denoted as either z¯z¯ or z∗z∗.

zz∗==(a+bi)(a−bi)z=(a+bi)z∗=(a−bi)

The product of a complex number and its conjugate gives a special result.

zz∗zz∗=====(a+bi)(a−bi)(a+bi)(a−bi)a2−abi+abi+b2a2+b2z=(a+bi)z∗=(a−bi)zz∗=(a+bi)(a−bi)=a2−abi+abi+b2=a2+b2

Absolute Value of a Complex Number

We can use the conjugate of a complex number to compute the absolute value (or norm, or magnitude) of a complex number. The absolute value of a complex number is the square-root of the complex number multiplied by its conjugate and is denoted |z||z|:

z|z|====(a+bi)zz∗−−−√(a+bi)(a−bi)−−−−−−−−−−−−√a2+b2−−−−−−√z=(a+bi)|z|=zz∗=(a+bi)(a−bi)=a2+b2

Quotient of Two Complex Numbers

To compute the quotient of two complex numbers, we multiply the numerator and denominator by the complex conjugate of the denominator.

z1z2z1z2======(a1+b1i)(a2+b2i)a1+b1ia2+b2i(a1+b1i)(a2−b2i)(a2+b2i)(a2−b2i)a1a2−a1b2i+b1a2i−b1b2i2a22+b22a1a2+b1b2a22+b22+b1a2−a1b2a22+b22iz1=(a1+b1i)z2=(a2+b2i)z1z2=a1+b1ia2+b2i=(a1+b1i)(a2−b2i)(a2+b2i)(a2−b2i)=a1a2−a1b2i+b1a2i−b1b2i2a22+b22=a1a2+b1b2a22+b22+b1a2−a1b2a22+b22i

Powers of ii

If we state that i2=−1i2=−1 then it should be possible to raise ii to other powers as well.

i0i1i2i3i4i5i6=======ii2i2i2ii4ii5====i2=1i−1−i1i−1i0=1i1=ii2=−1i3=ii2=−ii4=i2i2=1i5=ii4=ii6=ii5=i2=−1

If we keep writing this sequence, we will see a pattern emerge (1,i,−1,−i,1,…)(1,i,−1,−i,1,…).

A similar pattern emerges from the increasing negative powers.

i0i−1i−2i−3i−4i−5i−6=======1−i−1i1−i−1i0=1i−1=−ii−2=−1i−3=ii−4=1i−5=−ii−6=−1

You may have seen a similar pattern in mathematics before but in the form (x,y,−x,−y,x,…)(x,y,−x,−y,x,…) which is generated by rotating a point 90° counter-clockwise on a 2D Cartesian plane and the sequence (x,−y,−x,y,x,…)(x,−y,−x,y,x,…) is generated by rotating a point 90° clockwise on a 2D Cartesian plane.

Cartesian Plane

The Complex Plane

We can also map complex numbers in a 2D grid called the Complex Plane by mapping the Real part on the horizontal axis and the Imaginary part on the vertical axis.

Complex Plane

As shown in the previous sequence, we can say that if we multiply a complex number by ii, we can rotate the complex number through the complex plane at 90° increments.

Let’s see if this is true. We’ll take an arbitrary point pp in the complex plane:

p=2+ip=2+i

and we multiply it by ii gives qq:

pq=====2+ipi(2+i)i2i+i2−1+2ip=2+iq=pi=(2+i)i=2i+i2=−1+2i

Multiplying qq by ii gives rr:

qr=====−1+2iqi(−1+2i)i−i+2i2−2−iq=−1+2ir=qi=(−1+2i)i=−i+2i2=−2−i

And multiplying rr by ii gives ss:

rs=====−2−iri(−2−i)i−2i−i21−2ir=−2−is=ri=(−2−i)i=−2i−i2=1−2i

And multiplying ss by ii gives tt:

st=====1−2isi(1−2i)ii−2i22+is=1−2it=si=(1−2i)i=i−2i2=2+i

Which is exactly what we started with (pp). If we plot these complex numbers on the complex plane, we get the following result.

Complex Numbers on the Complex Plane

We can also rotate clock-wise in the complex plane by multiplying the complex number by −i−i.

Rotors

We can also perform arbitrary rotations in the complex plane by defining a complex number of the form:

q=cosθ+isinθq=cos⁡θ+isin⁡θ

Multiplying any complex number by the rotor qq produces the general formula:

pqpqa′+b′i====a+bicosθ+isinθ(a+bi)(cosθ+isinθ)acosθ−bsinθ+(asinθ+bcosθ)ip=a+biq=cos⁡θ+isin⁡θpq=(a+bi)(cos⁡θ+isin⁡θ)a′+b′i=acos⁡θ−bsin⁡θ+(asin⁡θ+bcos⁡θ)i

Which can also be written in matrix form:

[a′b′−b′a′]=[cosθsinθ−sinθcosθ][ab−ba][a′−b′b′a′]=[cos⁡θ−sin⁡θsin⁡θcos⁡θ][a−bba]

Which is the method to rotate an arbitrary point in the complex plane counter-clockwise about the origin.

Quaternions

With this knowledge of the complex number system and the complex plane, we can extend this to 3-dimensional space by adding two imaginary numbers to our number system in addition to ii.

The general form to express quaternions is

q=s+xi+yj+zk  s,x,y,z∈Rq=s+xi+yj+zk  s,x,y,z∈R

Where, according to Hamilton’s famous expression:

i2=j2=k2=ijk=−1i2=j2=k2=ijk=−1

and

ij=kji=−kjk=ikj=−iki=jik=−jij=kjk=iki=jji=−kkj=−iik=−j

You may have noticed that the relationship between ii, jj, and kk are very similar to the cross product rules for the unit cartesian vectors:

x×y=zy×x=−zy×z=xz×y=−xz×x=yx×z=−yx×y=zy×z=xz×x=yy×x=−zz×y=−xx×z=−y

Hamilton also recognized that the ii, jj, and kk imaginary numbers could be used to represent three cartesian unit vectors ii, jj, and kk with the same properties of imaginary numbers, such that i2=j2=k2=−1i2=j2=k2=−1.

Visualizing the Properties of ijij, jkjk, kiki

The image above visualizes the relationship between the cartesian unit vectors represented by ii, jj, and kk.

Quaternions as an Ordered Pair

We can also represent quaternions as an ordered pair:

q=[s,v]  s∈R,v∈R3q=[s,v]  s∈R,v∈R3

Where vv can also be represented by its individual components:

q=[s,xi+yj+zk]  s,x,y,z∈Rq=[s,xi+yj+zk]  s,x,y,z∈R

Using this notation, we can more easily show the similarities between quaternions and complex numbers.

Adding and Subtracting Quaternions

Quaternions can be added and subtracted similar to complex numbers:

qaqbqa+qbqa−qb====[sa,a][sb,b][sa+sb,a+b][sa−sb,a−b]qa=[sa,a]qb=[sb,b]qa+qb=[sa+sb,a+b]qa−qb=[sa−sb,a−b]

Quaternion Products

We can also express the product of two quaternions:

qaqbqaqb=====[sa,a][sb,b][sa,a][sb,b](sa+xai+yaj+zak)(sb+xbi+ybj+zbk)(sasb−xaxb−yayb−zazb)+(saxb+sbxa+yazb−ybza)i+(sayb+sbya+zaxb−zbxa)j+(sazb+sbza+xayb−xbya)kqa=[sa,a]qb=[sb,b]qaqb=[sa,a][sb,b]=(sa+xai+yaj+zak)(sb+xbi+ybj+zbk)=(sasb−xaxb−yayb−zazb)+(saxb+sbxa+yazb−ybza)i+(sayb+sbya+zaxb−zbxa)j+(sazb+sbza+xayb−xbya)k

Which results in another quaternion. If we replace the imaginary numbers ii, jj, and kk in the previous expression by the ordered pairs (also known as the quaternion units),

i=[0,i] j=[0,j] k=[0,k]i=[0,i] j=[0,j] k=[0,k]

And substituting back to the original expression together with [1,0]=1[1,0]=1 gives:

[sa,a][sb,b]=(sasb−xaxb−yayb−zazb)[1,0]+(saxb+sbxa+yazb−ybza)[0,i]+(sayb+sbya+zaxb−zbxa)[0,j]+(sazb+sbza+xayb−xbya)[0,k][sa,a][sb,b]=(sasb−xaxb−yayb−zazb)[1,0]+(saxb+sbxa+yazb−ybza)[0,i]+(sayb+sbya+zaxb−zbxa)[0,j]+(sazb+sbza+xayb−xbya)[0,k]

And expanding this expression into a sum of ordered pairs gives:

[sa,a][sb,b]=[sasb−xaxb−yayb−zazb,0]+[0,(saxb+sbxa+yazb−ybza)i]+[0,(sayb+sbya+zaxb−zbxa)j]+[0,(sazb+sbza+xayb−xbya)k][sa,a][sb,b]=[sasb−xaxb−yayb−zazb,0]+[0,(saxb+sbxa+yazb−ybza)i]+[0,(sayb+sbya+zaxb−zbxa)j]+[0,(sazb+sbza+xayb−xbya)k]

If we multiply through with the quaternion unit and extract the common vector components, we can rewrite this equation in this way:

[sa,a][sb,b]=[sasb−xaxb−yayb−zazb,0]+[0,sa(xbi+ybj+zbk)+sb(xai+yaj+zak)+(yazb−ybza)i+(zaxb−zbxa)j+(xayb−xbya)k][sa,a][sb,b]=[sasb−xaxb−yayb−zazb,0]+[0,sa(xbi+ybj+zbk)+sb(xai+yaj+zak)+(yazb−ybza)i+(zaxb−zbxa)j+(xayb−xbya)k]

This equation gives us the sum of two ordered pairs. The first ordered pair is a Real quaternion and the second is a Pure quaternion. These two ordered pairs can be combined into a single ordered pair:

[sa,a][sb,b]=[sasb−xaxb−yayb−zazb,sa(xbi+ybj+zbk)+sb(xai+yaj+zak)+(yazb−ybza)i+(zaxb−zbxa)j+(xayb−xbya)k][sa,a][sb,b]=[sasb−xaxb−yayb−zazb,sa(xbi+ybj+zbk)+sb(xai+yaj+zak)+(yazb−ybza)i+(zaxb−zbxa)j+(xayb−xbya)k]

And if we substitute,

aba⋅ba×b====xai+yaj+zakxbi+ybj+zbkxaxb+yayb+zazb(yazb−ybza)i+(zaxb−zbxa)j+(xayb−xbya)ka=xai+yaj+zakb=xbi+ybj+zbka⋅b=xaxb+yayb+zazba×b=(yazb−ybza)i+(zaxb−zbxa)j+(xayb−xbya)k

We get:

[sa,a][sb,b]=[sasb−a⋅b,sab+sba+a×b][sa,a][sb,b]=[sasb−a⋅b,sab+sba+a×b]

Which is the general equation of a quaternion product.

A Real Quaternion

A Real Quaternion is a quaternion with a vector term of 00:

q=[s,0]q=[s,0]

And the product of two Real Quaternions is another Real Quaternion:

qaqbqaqb====[sa,0][sb,0][sa,0][sb,0][sasb,0]qa=[sa,0]qb=[sb,0]qaqb=[sa,0][sb,0]=[sasb,0]

Which is similar to the product of two complex numbers that contain a zero imaginary term.

z1z2z1z2====a1+0ia2+0i(a1+0i)(a2+0i)a1a2z1=a1+0iz2=a2+0iz1z2=(a1+0i)(a2+0i)=a1a2

Multiplying a Quaternion by a Scalar

We can also multiply a quaternion by a scalar which should obey the rule:

qλq===[s,v]λ[s,v][λs,λv]q=[s,v]λq=λ[s,v]=[λs,λv]

We can confirm this by using the product or Real Quaterions shown above to multiply a quaternion by the scalar as a Real Quaternion:

qλλq====[s,v][λ,0][λ,0][s,v][λs,λv]q=[s,v]λ=[λ,0]λq=[λ,0][s,v]=[λs,λv]

Pure Quaternions

Similar to Real Quaterions, Hamilton also defined the Pure Quaternion as a quaternion that has a zero scalar term:

q=[0,v]q=[0,v]

Or, written in its component parts:

q=xi+yj+zkq=xi+yj+zk

And we can also take the product of two Pure quaternions:

qaqbqaqb====[0,a][0,b][0,a][0,b][−a⋅b,a×b]qa=[0,a]qb=[0,b]qaqb=[0,a][0,b]=[−a⋅b,a×b]

According to the quaternion product rule shown above.

Additive Form of a Quaternion

We can also express quaternions as an addition of the Real and Pure quaternion parts:

q==[s,v][s,0]+[0,v]q=[s,v]=[s,0]+[0,v]

Unit Quaternion

Given an arbitrary vector vv, we can express this vector in both its scalar magnitude and its direction as such:

v=vv^ where v=|v| and |v^|=1v=vv^ where v=|v| and |v^|=1

And combining this definition with the definition of a pure quaternion gives:

q===[0,v][0,vv^]v[0,v^]q=[0,v]=[0,vv^]=v[0,v^]

And we can also describe a unit quaternion that has a zero scalar and a unit vector as such:

q^=[0,v^]q^=[0,v^]

Binary Form of a Quaternion

We can now combine the definitions of the unit quaternion and the additive form of a quaternion, we can create a representation of quaternions which is similar to the notation used to describe complex numbers:

q====[s,v][s,0]+[0,v][s,0]+v[0,v^]s+vq^q=[s,v]=[s,0]+[0,v]=[s,0]+v[0,v^]=s+vq^

This gives us a way to represent the quaternion that is very similar to complex numbers:

zq==a+bis+vq^z=a+biq=s+vq^

Quaternion Conjugate

The quaternion conjugate can be computed by negating the vector part of the quaternion:

qq∗==[s,v][s,−v]q=[s,v]q∗=[s,−v]

And the product of a quaternion with its conjugate gives:

qq∗====[s,v][s,−v][s2−v⋅−v,−sv+sv+v×−v][s2+v⋅v,0][s2+v2,0]qq∗=[s,v][s,−v]=[s2−v⋅−v,−sv+sv+v×−v]=[s2+v⋅v,0]=[s2+v2,0]

Quaternion Norm

If you recall from the definition of the norm of a complex number:

|z|zz∗==a2+b2−−−−−−√|z|2|z|=a2+b2zz∗=|z|2

Similarly, the norm (or magnitude) of a quaternion is defined as:

q|q|==[s,v]s2+v2−−−−−−√q=[s,v]|q|=s2+v2

Which allows us to express the norm of a quaternion as:

qq∗=|q|2qq∗=|q|2

Quaternion Normalization

With the definition of a quaternion norm, we can use it to normalize a quaternion. A quaternion is normalized by dividing it by |q||q|:

q′=qs2+v2−−−−−−√q′=qs2+v2

As an example, let’s normalize the quaternion:

q=[1,4i+4j−4k]q=[1,4i+4j−4k]

First, we must compute the norm of the quaternion:

|q|===12+42+42+(−4)2−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−√49−−√7|q|=12+42+42+(−4)2=49=7

Then, we must divide the quaternion by the norm of the quaternion to compute the normalized quaternion:

q′===q|q|(1+4i+4j−4k)717+47i+47j−47kq′=q|q|=(1+4i+4j−4k)7=17+47i+47j−47k

Quaternion Inverse

The inverse of a quaternion is denoted q−1q−1. To compute the inverse of a quaternion, we take the conjugate of the quaternion and divide it by the square of the norm:

q−1=q∗|q|2q−1=q∗|q|2

To show this, we can take the fact that by definition of the inverse:

qq−1=[1,0]=1qq−1=[1,0]=1

And multiply both sides by the conjugate of the quaternion gives:

q∗qq−1=q∗q∗qq−1=q∗

And by substitution we get:

|q|2q−1q−1==q∗q∗|q|2|q|2q−1=q∗q−1=q∗|q|2

And for unit-norm quaternions whose norm is 1, we can write:

q−1=q∗q−1=q∗

Quaternion Dot Product

Similar to vector dot-products, we can also compute the dot product between two quaternions by multiplying the corresponding scalar parts and summing the results:

q1q2q1⋅q2===[s1,x1i+y1j+z1k][s2,x2i+y2j+z2k]s1s2+x1x2+y1y2+z1z2q1=[s1,x1i+y1j+z1k]q2=[s2,x2i+y2j+z2k]q1⋅q2=s1s2+x1x2+y1y2+z1z2

We can also use the quaternion dot-product to compute the angular difference between the quaternions:

cosθ=s1s2+x1x2+y1y2+z1z2|q1||q2|cos⁡θ=s1s2+x1x2+y1y2+z1z2|q1||q2|

And for unit-norm quaternions, we can simplify the equation:

cosθ=s1s2+x1x2+y1y2+z1z2cos⁡θ=s1s2+x1x2+y1y2+z1z2

Rotations

If you recall we defined a special form of the complex number called a Rotor that could be used to rotate a point through the 2D complex plane as:

q=cosθ+isinθq=cos⁡θ+isin⁡θ

Then by its similarities to complex numbers, it should be possible to express a quaternion that can be used to rotate a point in 3D-space as such:

q=[cosθ,sinθv]q=[cos⁡θ,sin⁡θv]

Let’s test if this theory holds by computing the product of the quaternion qq and the vector pp. First, we can express pp as a Pure quaternion in the form:

p=[0,p]p=[0,p]

And qq is a unit-norm quaternion in the form:

q=[s,λv^]q=[s,λv^]

Then,

p′===qp[s,λv^][0,p][−λv^⋅p,sp+λv^×p]p′=qp=[s,λv^][0,p]=[−λv^⋅p,sp+λv^×p]

We see that the result is a general quaternion with both scalar and a vector parts.

Let’s first consider the “special” case where pp is perpendicular to v^v^ in which case, the dot-product term −λv^⋅p=0−λv^⋅p=0 and the result becomes the Pure quaternion:

p′=[0,sp+λv^×p]p′=[0,sp+λv^×p]

In this case, to rotate pp about v^v^ we just substitute s=cosθs=cos⁡θ and λ=sinθλ=sin⁡θ.

p′=[0,cosθp+sinθv^×p]p′=[0,cos⁡θp+sin⁡θv^×p]

As an example, let’s rotate a vector pp 45° about the z-axis then our quaternion qq is:

q==[cosθ,sinθk][2√2,2√2k]q=[cos⁡θ,sin⁡θk]=[22,22k]

And let’s take a vector pp that adheres to the special case that pp is perpendicular to kk:

p=[0,2i]p=[0,2i]

Now let’s find the product of qpqp:

p′====qp[2√2,2√2k][0,2i][0,22√2i+22√2k×i][0,2–√i+2–√j]p′=qp=[22,22k][0,2i]=[0,222i+222k×i]=[0,2i+2j]

Which results in a Pure quaternion that is rotated 45° about the kk axis. We can also confirm that the magnitude of the resulting vector is maintained:

|p′|==2–√2+2–√2−−−−−−−−−√2|p′|=22+22=2

Which is exactly the result we expected!

We can visualize this by the following image:

Quaternion Rotation (1)

Now let’s consider a quaternion that is not orthogonal to pp. If we specify the vector part of our quaternion to 45° offset from pp we get:

v^pqp====2√2i+2√2k2i[cosθ,sinθv^][0,p]v^=22i+22kp=2iq=[cos⁡θ,sin⁡θv^]p=[0,p]

And multiplying our vector pp by qq we get:

p′===qp[cosθ,sinθv^][0,p][−sinθv^⋅p,cosθp+sinθv^×p]p′=qp=[cos⁡θ,sinθv^][0,p]=[−sin⁡θv^⋅p,cos⁡θp+sin⁡θv^×p]

And substituting v^v^, pp and θ=45∘θ=45∘ gives:

p′==[−2√2(2√2i+2√2k)⋅(2i),2√22i+2√2(2√2i+2√2k)×2i][−1,2–√i+j]p′=[−22(22i+22k)⋅(2i),222i+22(22i+22k)×2i]=[−1,2i+j]

Which is no longer a pure quaternion, and it has not been rotated 45° and the vector’s norm is no longer 2 (instead it has been reduced to 3–√3).

This result can be visualized by the image.

Quaternion Rotation (2)

Technically, it’s incorrect to represent the quaternion p′p′ in 3D space because it’s actually a 4D vector! For the sake of simplicity, I will only visualize the vector component of quaternions.

However, all is not lost. Hamilton recognized (but didn’t publish) that if we post-multiply the result of qpqp by the inverse of qq then the result is a pure quaternion and the norm of the vector component is maintained. Let’s see if we can apply this to our example.

First, let’s compute q−1q−1:

qq−1==[cosθ,sinθ(2√2i+2√2k)][cosθ,−sinθ(2√2i+2√2k)]q=[cos⁡θ,sin⁡θ(22i+22k)]q−1=[cos⁡θ,−sin⁡θ(22i+22k)]

For θ=45∘θ=45∘ gives:

q−1==[2√2,−2√2(2√2i+2√2k)]12[2–√,−i−k]q−1=[22,−22(22i+22k)]=12[2,−i−k]

And combining the previous value of qpqp and q−1q−1 gives:

qpqpq−1=====[−1,2–√i+j][−1,2–√i+j]12[2–√,−i−k]12[−2–√−(2–√i+j)⋅(−i−k),i+k+2–√(2–√i+j)−i+2–√j+k]12[−2–√+2–√,i+k+2i+2–√j−i+2–√j+k][0,i+2–√j+k]qp=[−1,2i+j]qpq−1=[−1,2i+j]12[2,−i−k]=12[−2−(2i+j)⋅(−i−k),i+k+2(2i+j)−i+2j+k]=12[−2+2,i+k+2i+2j−i+2j+k]=[0,i+2j+k]

Which is a pure quaternion and the norm of the result is:

|p′|===12+2–√2+12−−−−−−−−−−−√4–√2|p′|=12+22+12=4=2

which is the same as pp so the norm of the vector is maintained.

The image below visualizes the result of the rotation.

Quaternion Rotation (3)

So we can see that the result is a pure quaternion and that the norm of the initial vector is maintained, but the vector has been rotated 90° rather than 45° which is twice as much as desired! So in order to correctly rotate a vector pp by an angle θθ about an arbitrary axis v^v^, we must consider the half-angle and construct the following quaternion:

q=[cos12θ,sin12θv^]q=[cos⁡12θ,sin⁡12θv^]

Which is the general form of a rotation quaternion!

Quaternion Interpolation

One of the most important reasons for using quaternions in computer graphics is that quaternions are very good at representing rotations in space. Quaternions overcome the issues that plague other methods of rotating points in 3D space such as Gimbal lock which is an issue when you represent your rotation with euler angles.

Using quaternions, we can define several methods that represents a rotational interpolation in 3D space. The first method I will examine is called SLERP which is used to smoothly interpolate a point between two orientations. The second method is an extension of SLERP called SQAD which is used to interpolate through a sequence of orientations that define a path.

SLERP

SLERP stands for Spherical Linear Interpolation. SLERP provides a method to smoothly interpolate a point about two orientations.

I will represent the first orientation as q1q1 and the second orientation as q2q2. The point that is interpolated will be represented by pp and the interpolated point will be represented by p′p′. The interpolation parameter tt will interpolate pp from q1q1 when t=0t=0 to q2q2 when t=1t=1.

The standard linear interpolation formula is:

p′=p1+t(p2−p1)p′=p1+t(p2−p1)

The general steps to apply this equation are:

  • Compute the difference between p1p1 and p2p2.
  • Take the fractional part of that difference.
  • Adjust the original value by the fractional difference between the two points.

We can use the same basic principle to interpolate between two quaternion orientations.

Quaternion Difference

The first step dictates that we must compute the difference between q1q1 and q2q2. With regards to quaternions, this is equivalent to computing the angular difference between the two quaternions.

Δq=q−11q2Δq=q1−1q2

Quaternion Exponentiation

The next step is to take the fractional part of that difference. We can compute the fractional part of a quaternion by raising it to a power whose value is in the range [0…1][0…1].

The general formula for quaternion exponentiation is:

qt=exp(tlogq)qt=exp⁡(tlog⁡q)

Where the exponential function for quaternions is given by:

exp(q)==exp([0,θv^])[cosθ,sinθv^]exp⁡(q)=exp⁡([0,θv^])=[cos⁡θ,sin⁡θv^]

And the logarithm of a quaternion is given by:

logq====log(cosθ+sinθv^)log(exp(θv^))θv^[0,θv^]log⁡q=log⁡(cos⁡θ+sin⁡θv^)=log⁡(exp⁡(θv^))=θv^=[0,θv^]

For t=0t=0, we have:

q0====exp(0logq)exp([cos(0),sin(0)v^])exp([1,0])[1,0]q0=exp⁡(0log⁡q)=exp⁡([cos⁡(0),sin⁡(0)v^])=exp⁡([1,0])=[1,0]

And for t=1t=1, we have:

q1==exp(logq)qq1=exp⁡(log⁡q)=q

Fractional Difference of Quaternions

To compute the interpolated angular rotation, we adjust the original orientation q1q1 by the fractional part of the difference between q1q1 and q2q2.

q′=q1(q−11q2)tq′=q1(q1−1q2)t

Which is the general form of spherical linear interpolation using quaternions. However, this is not the form of the SLERP equation that is commonly used in practice.

We can apply a similar formula for performing a spherical interpolation of vectors to quaternions. The general form of a spherical interpolation for vectors is defined as:

vt=sin(1−t)θsinθv1+sintθsinθv2vt=sin⁡(1−t)θsin⁡θv1+sin⁡tθsin⁡θv2

This is visualized in the following image.

Quaternion Interpolation

This formula can be applied unmodified to quaternions:

qt=sin(1−t)θsinθq1+sintθsinθq2qt=sin⁡(1−t)θsin⁡θq1+sin⁡tθsin⁡θq2

And we can obtain the angle θθ by computing the dot-product between q1q1 and q2q2.

cosθθ===q1⋅q2|q1||q2|s1s2+x1x2+y1y2+z1z2|q1||q2|cos−1(s1s2+x1x2+y1y2+z1z2|q1||q2|)cos⁡θ=q1⋅q2|q1||q2|=s1s2+x1x2+y1y2+z1z2|q1||q2|θ=cos−1⁡(s1s2+x1x2+y1y2+z1z2|q1||q2|)

Considerations

There are two issues with this implementation which must be taken into consideration during implementation.

First, if the quaternion dot-product results in a negative value, then the resulting interpolation will travel the “long-way” around the 4D sphere which is not necessarily what we want. To solve this problem, we can test the result of the dot product and if it is negative, then we can negate one of the orientations. Negating the scalar and the vector part of the quaternion does not change the orientation that it represents but by doing this we guarantee that the rotation will be applied in the “shortest” path.

The other problem arises when the angular difference between q1q1 and q2q2 is very small then sinθsin⁡θ becomes 0. If this happens, then we will get an undefined result when we divide by sinθsin⁡θ. In this case, we can fall-back to using linear interpolation between q1q1 and q2q2.

SQUAD

Just as a SLERP can be used to compute an interpolation between two quaternions, a SQUAD (Spherical and Quadrangle) can be used to smoothly interpolate over a path of rotations.

If we have the sequence of quaternions:

q1,q2,q3,⋯,qn−2,qn−1,qnq1,q2,q3,⋯,qn−2,qn−1,qn

And we also define the “helper” quaternion (sisi) which we can consider an intermediate control point:

si=exp(−log(qi+1q−1i)+log(qi−1q−1i)4)qisi=exp⁡(−log⁡(qi+1qi−1)+log⁡(qi−1qi−1)4)qi

Then the orientation along the sub-cuve defined by:

qi−1,qi,qi+1,qi+2qi−1,qi,qi+1,qi+2

at time t is given by:

squad(qi,qi+1,si,si+1,t)=slerp(slerp(qi,qi+1,t),slerp(si,si+1,t),2t(1−t))squad(qi,qi+1,si,si+1,t)=slerp(slerp(qi,qi+1,t),slerp(si,si+1,t),2t(1−t))

Conclusion

Despite being extremely difficult to understand, quaternions provide a few obvious advantages over using matrices or Euler angles for representing rotations.

  • Quaternion interpolation using SLERP and SQUAD provide a way to interpolate smoothly between orientations in space.
  • Rotation concatenation using quaternions is faster than combining rotations expressed in matrix form.
  • For unit-norm quaternions, the inverse of the rotation is taken by subtracting the vector part of the quaternion. Computing the inverse of a rotation matrix is considerably slower if the matrix is not orthonormalized (if it is, then it’s just the transpose of the matrix).
  • Converting quaternions to matrices is slightly faster than for Euler angles.
  • Quaternions only require 4 numbers (3 if they are normalized. The Real part can be computed at run-time) to represent a rotation where a matrix requires at least 9 values.

However for all of the advantages in favor of using quaternions, there are also a few disadvantages.

  • Quaternions can become invalid because of floating-point round-off error however this “error creep” can be resolved by re-normalizing the quaternion.
  • And probably the most significant deterrent for using quaternions is that they are very hard to understand. I hope that this issue is resolved after reading this article.

There are several math libraries that implement quaternions and a few of those libraries implement quaternions correctly. In my personal experience, I find GLM (OpenGL Math Library) to be a good math library with a good implementation of quaternions. If you are interested in using quaternions in your own applications, this is the library I would recommend.

Download the Demo

I created a small demo that demonstrates how a quaternion is used to rotate an object in space. The demo was created with Unity 3.5.2 which you can download for free and view the demo script files. The zip file also contains a Windows binary executable but Using Unity, you can also generate a Mac application (and Unity 4 introduces Linux builds as well).

      Gaz,

      You are right about the fact that [math]\mathbf{i}^2=\mathbf{j}^2=\mathbf{k}^2=-1[/math] as is stated in the section titled Quaternions.

      Maybe if I write the product rule like this:

      [math]
      qaqbqaqb=====[sa,a][sb,b][sa,a][sb,b](sa+xai+yaj+zak)(sb+xbi+ybj+zbk)(sasb+xaxbi2+yaybj2+zazbk2)+(saxb+sbxa+yazb−ybza)i+(sayb+sbya+zaxb−zbxa)j+(sazb+sbza+xayb−xbya)kqa=[sa,a]qb=[sb,b]qaqb=[sa,a][sb,b]=(sa+xai+yaj+zak)(sb+xbi+ybj+zbk)=(sasb+xaxbi2+yaybj2+zazbk2)+(saxb+sbxa+yazb−ybza)i+(sayb+sbya+zaxb−zbxa)j+(sazb+sbza+xayb−xbya)k
      [/math]

      And we can write the dot product of the vector parts of the two quaternions as:

      [math]
      a⋅b===xaxbi2+yaybj2+zazbk2(−1)xaxb+(−1)yayb+(−1)zazb−(xaxb+yayb+zazb)a⋅b=xaxbi2+yaybj2+zazbk2=(−1)xaxb+(−1)yayb+(−1)zazb=−(xaxb+yayb+zazb)
      [/math]

      Which we can substitute back into the original equation:

      [math]
      [sa,a][sb,b]=(sasb−a⋅b)+(saxb+sbxa+yazb−ybza)i+(sayb+sbya+zaxb−zbxa)j+(sazb+sbza+xayb−xbya)k[sa,a][sb,b]=(sasb−a⋅b)+(saxb+sbxa+yazb−ybza)i+(sayb+sbya+zaxb−zbxa)j+(sazb+sbza+xayb−xbya)k
      [/math]

      So we are not adding any extra negatives, we are just factoring out the [math]\mathbf{i}^2=\mathbf{j}^2=\mathbf{k}^2=-1[/math] from the dot-product to get the real part of the quaternion product.

      Does this make it more clear?

There is some confusion in quaternion theory over when to treat i, j and k as imaginary numbers and when to treat them as unit vectors in the Cartesian system.

  21. akash on June 25, 2014 at 11:49 pm said:

    i have a doubt. when u calculate the norms int the example, u said, instead of 2 its is root(3). but how is it?? sqrt(1 + 2 + 1) = srt(4) = 2 ???

    Reply ↓
    • Jeremiah van Oosten on July 9, 2014 at 12:13 pm said:

      Akash,

      In the example we are rotating the vector [math]\mathbf{p}=2\mathbf{i}[/math] 45° by the quaternion [math]q=[\cos\theta,\sin\theta\mathbf{k}][/math] but in order to perform this operation, we must express [math]\mathbf{p}[/math] as a pure quaternion in the form [math]p=[0,\mathbf{p}][/math]. (notice how vectors are expressed use bold-face characters and quaternions are expressed as normal (not bold) characters).

      If the quaternion [math]q[/math] correctly rotated the vector [math]\mathbf{p}[/math] then the result should also be a pure quaternion (with no scalar part) and the magnitude of the vector part should be the same as the original vector (because a rotation should not scale the original vector) however this example shows that this is not the case.

      The magnitude of the original vector is

      [math]
      |p|==22−−√2|p|=22=2
      [/math]

      But the magnitude of the vector part of the resulting quaternion is:

      [math]
      |p′|===2–√2+12−−−−−−−√2+1−−−−√3–√|p′|=22+12=2+1=3
      [/math]

      Which is not the same magnitude as the original vector.

      If I wanted to compute the magnitude of the resulting quaternion then I would need to consider the quaternion’s scalar part according to the formula described in the section titled Quaternion Norm. But since I’m only interested in rotating a vector by a quaternion I only want to consider the result of the vector part (and thus discard the scalar part when I compute the magnitude of the resulting vector).

      I hope this answers your question.

      Reply ↓
  22. cubase01 on July 5, 2014 at 4:39 pm said:

    and I have a question.whats that suppose to mean?

    if a+bi is a point,isnt that a Matrix multipy a point equals to a point more correct?

    Reply ↓
    • Jeremiah van Oosten on July 9, 2014 at 2:42 pm said:

      cubase01,

      Sorry, the matrix representation of a complex number is not explained in this article. I will try to briefly explain it here.

      We can represent a complex number as the matrix [math]\mathbf{C}[/math] which is the sum of two other matrices representing the real [math]\mathbf{R}[/math] and the imaginary [math]\mathbf{I}[/math] parts (note that bold, upper-case characters represent matrices):

      [math]\mathbf{C}=\mathbf{R}+\mathbf{I}[/math]

      Which can also be expressed in the more familiar form of the complex number:

      [math]\mathbf{C}=a\mathbf{\hat{R}}+b\mathbf{\hat{I}}~~a,b\in\mathbb{R}[/math]

      where [math]\mathbf{\hat{R}}{\equiv}1[/math] and [math]\mathbf{\hat{I}}{\equiv}i[/math].

      The matrix equivalent of 1 is the 2 x 2 identity matrix:

      [math]\mathbf{\hat{R}}=
      [1001][1001]
      [/math]

      And as was mentioned in the section titled Powers of i the imaginary component [math]i[/math] can be treated as a 90° counter-clockwise rotation in the complex plane which can also be represented by a rotation matrix:

      [math]
      I^==[cos90∘sin90∘−sin90∘cos90∘][01−10]I^=[cos⁡90∘−sin⁡90∘sin⁡90∘cos⁡90∘]=[0−110]
      [/math]

      Now we can express the complex number in matrix form:

      [math]
      C===aR^+bI^a[1001]+b[01−10][ab−ba]C=aR^+bI^=a[1001]+b[0−110]=[a−bba]
      [/math]

      So what you see in the section titled Rotors is the matrix form of a complex number and the [math]a[/math] and [math]b[/math] are the real and imaginary parts of a complex number and rotating a complex number (represented in matrix form) by the 2×2 counter-clockwise rotation matrix produces another complex number (represented in matrix form).

      It is also interesting to note that if we express the equation [math]i^2=-1[/math] in matrix form we get:

      [math]
      [01−10][0−110]
      [01−10][0−110]
      = -1
      [1001][1001]
      [/math]

      which verifies that the square of the imaginary number is -1.

      I hope this helps.

      Reply ↓

  30. Stephen on March 5, 2016 at 3:05 pm said:

    • Jeremiah van Oosten on February 20, 2018 at 12:52 pm said:

      I’m sorry about the confusion. When the imaginary numbers (ii, jj, and kk) are shown using emphasis then they represent an imaginary number (along a particular imaginary axis). When they are shown in bold (ii, jj, and kk) then they represent the basis vectors in the cartesian plane (which have properties similar to the imaginary numbers). This is similar to how the real numbers (xx, yy, and zz) are used to represent the components of a 3D vector while the basis vectors are represented as xx, yy, and zz using a boldface font.

      I hope this answers you question.

  31. Jens on March 31, 2016 at 5:57 am said:

    Why would anyone use the that formula for SLERP which divides by sin(theta)?!

    ((1 – t) q_1 + t q_2)/sqrt(1 + 2 (q1*q2 – 1) (1 – t) t) also yields spherical interpolation, and with this, division by 0 happens only when q1 = -q2 where spherical interpolation isn’t well-defined, because there is no unique path from the north pole to the south pole which makes more sense than any other.

    Reply ↓
    • Jeremiah van Oosten on July 7, 2016 at 3:11 pm said:

      Jens,

      Can you provide a reference to your SLERP equation that shows a proof of the equation you are providing?

      The SLERP method that uses sinθsin⁡θ provides a method of spherical interpolation that maintains a constant angular velocity while rotating between q1q1 and q2q2. Note that it does not provide a method to maintain linear velocity over the curve. If the quaternions are not normalized, you may notice some “ease-in” and “ease-out” effects. But this is not a problem if the quaternions are normalized.

      Perhaps your formula can better achieve constant linear velocity while allowing for non-normalized quaternions?

  33. SImon on November 17, 2016 at 8:25 pm said:

    Found this great quote for visualization of quaternions. ”Imagine you have a small lump of clay and a load of tooth pics. Slide a tooth pick through the clay on each of it’s individual axis, X, Y and Z. Rotate the tooth picks, notice how the clay is being rotated on one of it’s axis at a time. This is how normal Euler axis work, and how most people understand rotation. Now, grab another tooth pick and jam it into the clay at any angle you want! Rotate the new tooth pick on it’s own axis, notice it isn’t constrained to the x, y or z axis but is rotating on it’s own ‘new’ and unique axis. This ^ is a quaternion, whenever you are reading up on them from now on, think of this example and hopefully it should make a little more sense.”

  41. babala_234 on November 28, 2017 at 10:41 am said:

    Thank you for the best explanation of quaternions! But I have one question about it: in the “rotation” part, you said the “the vector has been rotated 90° rather than 45°”. As the diagram showing, the pp vector is [2,0,0][2,0,0] and the p′p′ vector is [1,2–√,1][1,2,1], so the angle between them is cosθ=p⋅p′|p||p′|=12cos⁡θ=p⋅p′|p||p′|=12, that is θ=60 instead of 90. Am I right? Any suggestion are appreciated.

    Reply ↓
    • Jeremiah van Oosten on December 2, 2017 at 11:33 pm said:

      Babala,

      You are right that the dot product between the two pure quaternions (pp and p′p′ is 60° but in the example, pp is rotated 90° about the circle that is formed by the quaternion qq. The dot product of the quaternions is similar to that of vectors, it measures the angle formed between the two quaternions. In this case, its the linear angle between the two vectors pp and p′p′ but the the rotation is measured about the circle that is swept out by the rotation. Perhaps an image will help illustrate this.


      The image visualizes the rotation as observed from looking down the kk (zz) axis. In this image we see that the angle between pp and p′p′ is 60° but the semicircle swept out by the rotation is 90°. The next image shows it from a different angle.


      This image shows the exact same rotation but now we are looking directly at the axis of rotation. Now it can easily be observed that pp has been rotated exactly 90° about the quaternion axis.

      So the quaternion dot product does not measure the amount of rotation that is applied, but just the angle between the vector parts of the two quaternions.

      Keep in mind that if the point being rotated is very close to the axis of rotation, the circle swept by the rotation will be very small. In this case, the dot product between the original point and the rotated point may be very small (almost 0), but the amount the point was rotated could be ±180°

      I hope this answers your question.

      Reply ↓

  49. baris on May 20, 2019 at 1:53 pm said:

    Hey! First of all thanks for very nice article it is really helpful.

    I would like to point out an ambiguity in notations. In rotations section, q−1q−1 is actually the conjugate if I am not mistaken, not the inverse. Thus, it creates an ambiguity with the definitions made before and other articles about the topic. I would humbly suggest changing the rotation formulation to qpq∗qpq∗. Again ofc. if I am not mistaken:)

    Best
    Barış

    Reply ↓
    • Jeremiah on May 28, 2019 at 11:11 pm said:

      Baris,

      I checked several sources for quaternion notation and this is what I found:

      1. Quaternions for Computer Graphics (Vince, 2011) (the primary reference for this article) uses q∗q∗ to denote quaternion conjugate and q−1q−1 to denote quaternion inverse.
      2. Quaternion – Wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quaternion#Conjugation,_the_norm,_and_reciprocal) uses q∗q∗, q¯q¯, qtqt, or q~q~ to denote quaternion conjugate and also points out that the conjugate of a quaternion is also its own inverse (conjugating an element twice returns the original element).
      3. Mathematics for 3D Game Programming & Computer Graphics (Lengyel, 2012) uses q¯q¯ to denote quaternion conjugate and q−1q−1 to denote quaternion inverse.

      So from these references, I think it is safe to say that there is no ambiguity using q∗q∗ to denote the quaternion conjugate. Perhaps your confusion comes from the fact that the unit norm quaternion conjugate is the inverse. This is equivalent to the fact that the transpose of an orthonormalized matrix is its inverse.

      Reply ↓

    • Jeremiah on March 26, 2021 at 10:49 am said:

      I suppose it is not entirely accurate to visualize this relationship as a “rotation”. It’s more like a mnemonic to try to remember the relationship. If it helps you to think of it the other way around, then I suppose that is also valid.
      Another way I like to visualize it, is to place ii, jj, and kk in the columns of a matrix:

      ⎡⎣⎢⎢iiijjjkkkiiijjjkkk⎤⎦⎥⎥[ijkijkijkijkijkijk]

      Then, if you take the (forward) diagonal entries of the matrix , you get the same order. If you take the backward diagonal, you get the inverse:

      ij=kji=−kjk=ikj=−iki=jik=−jij=kjk=iki=jji=−kkj=−iik=−j

  60. fym chan on September 26, 2021 at 5:19 am said:

    It is very well presented. But some how two topics are left dangling:

    1. quaternions with half angles : q P q* will do the trick. can show it will result . And the vector part can be shown as a correct rotation.
    details: use unit vector v as i , v P plane as i j plane,
    vector v cross multiply vector P as k,
    and tilda = angle between v and P
    then: P= cos(tilda) i + sin(tilda) j
    q Pq* = cos(tilda)i+ sin(tilda)cos(theta)j+ sin(tilda)sin(theta)k
    where theta is angle of rotation

    then magnitude of one is reserved and space rotaton recognized.

  61. fym chan on September 26, 2021 at 5:45 am said:

    the second comment is the beautiful plot of vector Vt in the spherical interpolation. It is a pity to draw V1 and V2 as orthogonal.
    We can put V1 and V2 as two unit vectors on the unit circle, ( with V1 dot V2 =cos (theta) = cos(alpha+ beta)). Then it can be shown Vt = sin(beta)/sin(theta) V1+ sin(alpha)/sin(theta) V2 will also be a unit vector on the unit circle. In fact, Vt component in V1 direction is cos (alpha) and its V1 vertical component is sin (alpha). Hence, its magnitude is one, and lies on the unit circle. It will be interesting if we can show it in a picture here.
